channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel Releases Evidence It Says Shows Hamas Operates Near Civilian Shelters
item.description: The Israeli military posted unverified videos and maps that it claims showed rockets had been fired from areas in southern Gaza where civilians were seeking shelter.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourning Palestinians killed in a strike in Khan Younis in the Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: UK Accuses Russia of Yearslong Cyberattacks
item.description: The government said a group linked to Russia’s intelligence service carried out sustained operations to undermine trust in Britain’s political system.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Megan Specia and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attempts by Russia “to interfere in U.K. politics are completely unacceptable,” said David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, amid the accusations.

item.title: Israel Is Targeting Hamas With Battlefield Intelligence
item.description: Israel has recovered a trove of material that its military has used to assess the extent of the group’s attack plans, and its tactics and abilities, information reviewed by The Times shows.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier near a tank in Gaza City last month in a photograph taken while New York Times journalists were escorted in the enclave by the Israeli military.

item.title: Greece and Turkey, Long at Odds, Vow to Work Together Peacefully
item.description: The two rivals have been at the brink of military conflict several times in recent decades. An agreement signed by the countries’ leaders on Thursday aims to change that.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece, center, greeted President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Athens on Thursday before the two leaders signed a “declaration of friendship” pact.

item.title: Strike That Killed Reuters Journalist Was ‘Apparently Deliberate’ Israeli Attack, Group Says
item.description: Human Rights Watch found that the slain journalist and six colleagues were not near active fighting in southern Lebanon and would have been clearly visible to Israeli forces.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Hwaida Saad
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch on Thursday released findings from their investigations into the deadly strikes by Israel on southern Lebanon on Oct. 13.

item.title: What Kevin McCarthy and Rishi Sunak Have in Common: Unmanageable Parties
item.description: A former speaker of the U.S. House and the British prime minister have struggled to corral the extreme right factions of their parties.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain with Kevin McCarthy, the former House speaker, in Washington in June.

item.title: Ukraine Carries On Fight While Pondering an Erosion of U.S. Aid
item.description: The government in Kyiv remains hopeful of further American assistance, but it is also looking to other resources — and trying to make clear what could be at stake.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Lara Jakes and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a self-propelled howitzer in the Kharkiv region on Wednesday.

item.title: Seychelles Declares State of Emergency After Blast at Explosives Depot
item.description: Seychelles declared a state of emergency after the explosion, which came on the heels of deadly flooding in the country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and John Yoon
item.media:description: The explosion “has caused massive damage” to an industrial area called Providence, officials said.

item.title: Russia Sets Date for Presidential Election
item.description: The winner of the contest is widely seen as a foregone conclusion: Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow. The contest in March will be the first presidential election since Mr. Putin ordered the full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Feel the Bite of Polish Truckers’ Protest
item.description: A border blockade by haulers angry that the European Union has suspended a permit system for their Ukrainian counterparts has led to problems with deliveries of wartime supplies.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Trucks stuck near a border crossing between Poland and Ukraine in November. The blockade action is entering its second month and shows no signs of nearing a resolution.

item.title: Girl Kills Schoolmate and Wounds 5 in Russia Shooting
item.description: The authorities said investigators were working to establish the motive for the shooting, which took place in the city of Bryansk, near the border with Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: The regional governor of the Bryansk region called the shootings a “terrible tragedy.”

item.title: China and E.U. Leaders Met as Tensions Rise Over Russia
item.description: The European summit with China’s leader comes as relations have cooled over Beijing’s alignment with Russia in its war on Ukraine and a surge in Chinese exports.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Olivia Wang and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met with Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, and Charles Michel, the European Council president. The European leaders were planning to urge Beijing to use its influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Ireland’s Riot Was Not a Surprise to Those Who Watch the Far Right
item.description: The disorder in Dublin on Nov. 23 may have appeared to come from nowhere. But experts say it reflected long-running social problems and an emboldened anti-immigrant movement.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Putin Travels to U.A.E. and Saudi Arabia on Rare Trip to Mideast
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia stopped first in the United Arab Emirates and went on to Saudi Arabia. He said the Israel-Hamas war will figure prominently in his discussions.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: The United Arab Emirates Presidential Court, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the United Arab Emirates Presidential Court showed President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia greeting Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, the Emirati president, in Abu Dhabi on Wednesday.

item.title: Thomas Mayo on What Comes After Australia Rejected the Voice
item.description: Thomas Mayo was the calm champion of the effort in Australia to give Indigenous people a voice in Parliament. After its failure, will he turn up the volume?
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Adam Ferguson
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Mayo, an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leader, spent more than a year campaigning for an aboriginal voice to be added to the Australian constitution.

item.title: The Year in ‘Sensitive Content’
item.description: In 2023, Instagram served me images of dead and dying children, heightening social media’s contradictions to a horrific new level.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Hess

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Israeli allegations about Hamas’s tactics.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinians strike the concrete of a destroyed building while looking for survivors following Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis.

item.title: Biden Tied Ukraine Aid to Border Security, and It Backfired on Him
item.description: President Biden faces difficult choices about how far to go in giving in to conservative demands that he choke off the number of migrants admitted to the United States.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: A U.S. Border Patrol boat passing a large group of migrants crossing a razor wire barrier into the United States at Eagle Pass, Texas, in September. Republican lawmakers want the United States to impose policies that would make most migrants ineligible for asylum.

item.title: Israel Says It Detained Hundreds of Terrorism Suspects in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said that many had surrendered and been transferred to Israel for further questioning.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Explosions in Khan Younis as seen from Rafah on Thursday.

item.title: Israel Says Hamas Fired Rockets From Near Gaza Shelters
item.description: The claim adds to the growing concerns that there is no safe place in the enclave for those who have been displaced since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Yara Bayoumy, Aric Toler, Lauren Leatherby and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Palestinians evacuating a wounded woman after an explosion on Thursday in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Denmark Bans Quran Burning
item.description: The law came after a series of public Quran burnings in Scandinavia caused uproar in Muslim communities.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Justice Minister Peter Hummelgaard, second from the left, presenting a bill banning Quran burning, in August.

item.title: In Israel, Hanukkah Begins in the Shadow of Two Months of War
item.description: The holiday held a new meaning for many Israelis in the wake of the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks, including relatives of people still held hostage in Gaza and reservists called up to fight against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members and friends of the people held hostage in Gaza at a candle lighting ceremony in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Says Hamas Fired Rockets From Near Shelters
item.description: Plus, “Oppenheimer” is coming to Japan.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians who fled Khan Yunis set up camp in Rafah further south near the border with Egypt, on December 7, 2023, amid continuing battles between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas.

item.title: Son of Israeli War Cabinet Member Killed in Action in Gaza
item.description: Gal Meir Eisenkot, 25, was the son of Lt. Gen. Gadi Eisenkot, a former military chief who went into politics and is part of the group directing the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Gadi Eisenkot, a former chief of staff of the Israeli army, near Jerusalem in February. His son, Gadi, was killed in action in Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. and Mexico Try to Promote Trade While Curbing Flow of Fentanyl
item.description: In her Mexico City visit, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen sought to deepen economic ties while countering drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen had to strike a delicate balance in Mexico, pushing her counterparts there to work harder to confront fentanyl trafficking while trying to deepen economic ties.

item.title: A City-Size Iceberg Is Moving Out of Antarctic Waters
item.description: Next up, a yearslong ramble through the Southern Ocean and, eventually, a big melt.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Andrew Meijers/British Antarctic Survey, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A23a is a whole lot of ice. And it’s moving.

item.title: Here is what we know about Israel’s evidence that Hamas fired rockets from safe zones.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler and Lauren Leatherby

item.title: Benjamin Zephaniah, Poet of Social Justice Issues, Dies at 65
item.description: He opened the door for future generations of poets of color to use their own voices.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The British writer and poet Benjamin Zephaniah in Cambridgeshire, England, in 2021.

item.title: Particle Physicists Offer a Road Map For the Next Decade
item.description: A “muon shot” aims to study the basic forces of the cosmos. But meager federal budgets could limit its ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Katrina Miller
item.media:description: A tunnel of the Superconducting Super Collider project in 1993, which was abandoned by Congress.

item.title: Lawmakers Press Biden Administration for Tougher Curbs on China Tech
item.description: Republican legislators argue that the Biden administration has been ill-equipped and unmotivated in a technology fight with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee said the administration failed to enforce restrictions on sales of advanced technology to China.

item.title: U.S. Marshal Arrested After Unruly Behavior on Flight to London
item.description: The police in London said the 39-year-old “was disruptive and had sexually assaulted other passengers and crew.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The police in London received reports of a disruptive passenger from the staff on a Delta flight from Kennedy Airport.

item.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Will Be Released in Japan After Earlier Backlash
item.description: Critics said the film’s cross-promotion with “Barbie” trivialized the U.S. nuclear attacks on Japan during World War II, but the biopic will be released in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: “Oppenheimer” has since grossed nearly $1 billion in box office sales worldwide, but the film has not yet been screened in Japan.

item.title: Climate Change Makes East Africa’s Deadly Floods Worse, Study Finds
item.description: The extreme rain and flooding in Ethiopia, Kenya and Somalia this fall has been made twice as intense by climate change, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: A section of road destroyed by floods in Mororo in northeastern Kenya on Nov. 30.

item.title: Key Events in Israel and Gaza Since Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: On Oct. 7, Hamas and other militant groups launched an attack in Israel that killed hundreds. Israel responded with a military campaign that has devastated Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of the music festival a few days after Hamas opened fire on crowds of civilians in Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: Hundreds of thousands are sheltering in Al-Mawasi and the surrounding region, aid workers say.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Liam Stack and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle near the Israel-Gaza border on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A growing humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians on their way from the north of the Gaza Strip to its south.

item.title: Europe and Asia React to U.S. Push for Tech and Clean Energy
item.description: Other governments, particularly in Europe, are trying to counter the Biden administration’s industrial policies with their own incentives.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Jeanna Smialek, Alan Rappeport and Eshe Nelson
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Roseland Solar and Storage center in Riesel, Texas, has over 1.2 million solar panels on 4,263 acres. The United States has embarked on an enormous push to bolster its clean energy industry.

item.title: Russia’s Latest Disinformation Tactic Exploits American Celebrities
item.description: Videos from Elijah Wood, Mike Tyson and others have been used — unknowingly to them, it seems — in social media posts and Russian news coverage critical of Ukraine’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last year. Beginning in July, a Russian viral disinformation video campaign falsely accused him of having a substance abuse problem.

item.title: Despite McConnell Legacy Push, Ukraine Funding in Increasing Jeopardy
item.description: The minority leader, who many believe could step down next year, has found himself out of step with many fellow Senate Republicans on the question of keeping money flowing to the U.S. ally.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the minority leader, in the Capitol in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Venezuela Orders Arrest of Top Opposition Figures on Treason
item.description: The move is the latest of several that undercut prospects of free elections next year, despite commitments made to the Biden administration in return for sanctions relief.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Isayen Herrera
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, a Venezuelan opposition leader, held a news conference in Caracas on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Battle for a City in Gaza, Sparking Another Exodus
item.description: Thousands of people heeded Israeli orders to flee Khan Younis and nearby areas, but the places they were told to go had little shelter, water or food.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Shashank Bengali and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Palestinians searching for victims in the rubble left by a strike that touched off a blaze in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: Arizona Man Is Arrested in Connection With Australia Shooting
item.description: Two police officers and a bystander died in the shootout in Queensland last year.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Christine Hauser
item.media:description: Cheryl Scanlon, an assistant commissioner of the Queensland Police Service in Australia, announced the arrest of an Arizona man in connection with a shooting on a remote property on Dec. 12, 2022.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Gazans Flee Khan Younis
item.description: Plus, remembering Norman Lear.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Injured people arrive at Nasser Hospital, in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: New U.K. Asylum Bill Aims to Override Some Human Rights Law
item.description: Britain’s prime minister unveiled emergency legislation to salvage a highly contested scheme to deport asylum seekers to the African country. It wasn’t enough for his immigration minister.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The proposed bill by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain failed to satisfy hard-liners in his Conservative Party.

item.title: Republicans Block Aid to Ukraine, Jeopardizing Its Fight Against Russia
item.description: The vote spotlighted waning support in Congress for backing Ukraine in the war, and left the fate of the effort uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: White House and Ukrainian officials have told lawmakers that without an influx of weapons, Ukraine will run out of resources to defend against Russia by the end of the year.

item.title: Gaza Hostage Families Urge Israeli Government to Help
item.description: Released hostages met for the first time with Israel’s war cabinet, painting a grim portrait of captivity in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Photos of the Hamas hostages displayed in Tel Aviv on Wednesday.

item.title: Gazans Flee Fighting to Al-Mawasi, but Find Little Shelter There
item.description: Palestinians were told to go to the seaside village of Al-Mawasi to escape the fighting, but once they got there they found they were on their own.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Yara Bayoumy
item.media:description: Palestinians evacuating the city of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: U.N. Secretary General Invokes Article 99, Asking to Declare a Cease-Fire in Gaza
item.description: The move was a major step by the secretary general, António Guterres, in his efforts to stop the war, which he described as a humanitarian disaster that threatened international security.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, at the United Nations headquarters in New York in October.

item.title: Illia Kyva Is Killed Near Moscow
item.description: The lawmaker, Illia Kyva, called for Ukraine to surrender after Russia invaded. He was living in Russia, but Ukrainian authorities had sentenced him to prison in absentia on charges including treason.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Volodymyr Tarasov/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Former Ukrainian lawmaker Illia Kyva, right, in Kyiv in 2021.

item.title: Bordeaux Botulism Outbreak: Criminal Charges Announced
item.description: One person died and 15 others were sickened in September after eating homemade sardine preserves at an organic wine bar in Bordeaux. Prosecutors say hygiene rules were violated.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The Tchin Tchin Wine Bar in Bordeaux, France.

item.title: Israel Claims It Has Killed 5 Hamas Commanders Seen in Rare Photo
item.description: Israeli forces have been targeting the Hamas leadership since the group launched an attack on southern Israel on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman

item.title: U.S. Charges 4 Russian Soldiers With War Crimes Against an American
item.description: The Justice Department also said it had begun investigating the “murder of more than 30 Americans” by Hamas fighters during the Oct. 7 attack in Israel.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland announced charges against four Russian soldiers on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Calls on Congress to Approve Aid to Ukraine: ‘This Cannot Wait’
item.description: The administration has already alerted Congress that money for Ukraine will run out by the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden urged Congress in a televised speech on Wednesday to pass aid for Ukraine.

item.title: Nguyen Qui Duc, Whose Salon Became a Hanoi Hub, Dies at 65
item.description: A former refugee who found radio success in the U.S., he opened an exhibition space in his native Vietnam that drew artists and ambassadors. Anthony Bourdain dropped in.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans

item.title: Snob summer is dead. Long live mystery winter.
item.description: Settling in for a cozy season of whodunnits.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Alice Braga, left, and Emma Corrin in “A Murder at the End of the World.”

item.title: As Political Turmoil Intensifies in Ukraine, Opposition Leader Calls for Unity
item.description: Tensions between Ukrainian leaders, including between President Volodymyr Zelensky and his military chief, come as the country seeks emergency aid from Washington.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Petro O. Poroshenko on the outskirts of Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, in 2022. He had planned a trip to the United States for what he said were meetings at Congress and the Pentagon.

item.title: Can Carbon Capture Live Up to the Hype?
item.description: The technology to capture and bury carbon dioxide has struggled to ramp up and has real limits. But experts say it could play a valuable role.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Gaza War Widens Gap Between Arab Rulers and Citizens
item.description: Bahrain, a small Gulf monarchy, faces growing pressure from citizens to cut its recently established ties with Israel — a microcosm of the tensions spreading across the Mideast.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protests have become a frequent sight in Manama, Bahrain’s capital, since the war in Gaza began on Oct. 7.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Madrid
item.description: Like many who call Madrid home, Elena Medel was born elsewhere, but forged her identity in the Spanish capital. Here, she recommends books about this city that “refuses to be reduced to an ideal.”
item.dc:creator: Elena Medel

item.title: U.S. Military Grounds Hundreds of Ospreys After Fatal Crash Off Japan
item.description: The Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps said a problem with the aircraft may have caused the crash last week, which is believed to have killed eight airmen.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and Aishvarya Kavi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Debris believed to be from the CV-22 Osprey that crashed off the island of Yakushima in Japan on Nov. 29 was brought ashore last week.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Accounts of sexual violence by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden has become so closely associated with Israel that he effectively owns its military operation and has absorbed withering political attacks, especially from the left wing of his own party.

item.title: Boris Johnson Apologizes at U.K. Covid Inquiry for ‘Pain and Suffering’
item.description: The former prime minister said his government had initially underestimated the coronavirus. But he insisted that he and his aides had done the best they could at the time.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A screenshot from footage broadcast by Britain’s Covid-19 inquiry showed Boris Johnson, the former prime minister, testifying in London on Wednesday about his government’s handling of the pandemic.

item.title: Woman Shot and Killed in East London
item.description: Two other people were shot and injured in the shooting, a rarity in Britain. They were taken to a hospital and their status was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Carballo
item.media:credit: James Weech/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Police at the scene of a shooting incident near Vine Close, Hackney, east London on Wednesday.
